title: How many public DC fast charge electric vehicle charging stations will be available in the United States by 31 December 2020?
preds: Approx. 13.2/day this last week. It might be close if production bumps up against the ceiling of 4435.

" 60,000 public chargers up and running in the U.S. by the end of 2018. " (Quoted in article below)
Thankfully, the number of public EV charging stations is growing fast. Published reports suggest that there were close to 60,000 public chargers up and running in the U.S. by the end of 2018. They’re typically installed in apartment building and public parking garages, retail parking lots, at new-car dealerships, and even on some urban streets, with most located in areas with higher EV penetration.

11/13 = 4,128 stations 11/10= 4,109 stations. June 30 = 3799
up from 9/22= 4,001 recently that is 127 stations in 51 days for about 2.49/day more and there could be another 119 stations. 4128 + 119 = 4,247. This is a simplest model, but it seems to say there will be more than 4200.
GAME OVER

89 stations to go and 34 business days between now (Nov 11) and Dec 31. That means we have to average 2.6 stations per business day. Since July 28th we've averaged over 3 stations per day. We'll hit 4,200 but stay below 4,500.

11/10= 4,109 stations. June 30 = 3799
up from 9/22= 4,001 recently that is 108 stations in 48 days for about 2.25/day more and there could be another 117 stations. 4109 + 117 = 4,226. This is a simplist model, but it seems to say there will be more than 4200.

11/2= 4,091 stations. June 30 = 3799
up from 9/22= 4,001 recently that is 90 stations in 41 days for about 2.19/day more and there could be another 130 stations. 4091 + 130 = 4,221.
48 working days remaining until Dec 31. Since I started logging progress on July 28 we've averaged 3.1 stations per working day. We're on target to hit 215.
Recent surges place us on track to hit 4,200.

Big numbers over the past 2 days put the daily average since I started tracking in July up over 3 per working day. With 43 working days to go we're on target to hit 4,208. I'm swinging more to the third bin but not ready to go all in....
Too many days with an average below 3. On target to hit around 4,150.

10/22= 4,060 stations. June 30 = 3799
up from 9/22= 4,001 recently that is 59 stations in 30 days for about 1.9666/day more and there could be another 135 stations. 4060 + 135 = 4195....right on the bubble....that is why I am fence sitting.

10/18= 4,050 stations. June 30 = 3799
up from 9/22= 4,001 recently that is 49 stations in 26 days for about 1.88/day more and there could be another 140 stations. 4050 + 140 = 4190....right on the bubble....that is why I am fence sitting.
I am still getting a number smaller than 4200 using linear extrapolation. Budgets are hammered.  Season for construction has passed. I'll shoot for a pessimistic number under 4200, but close.
With adjusted average since June 30th at 3.3 per working day, and with 51 working days to go. Current count is 4,050. Projected end total is 4,218. This is a trend upwards.

71 working days between June 20 and October 8. 230 stations have been added during that timeframe for an average of 3.24. With 56 business days to go until this question closes, I project 181 additional stations, bringing us to a final total of 4,210.

10/7= 4,029 stations. June 30 = 3799
up from 9/22= 4,001 recently that is 28 stations in 15 days for about 1.8/day more and there could be another 160 stations. 4029 + 160 = 4189....right on the bubble....that is why I am fence sitting.
There were 230 stations in July/Aug/Sept/part Oct.

10/5= 4,023 stations. June 30 = 3799 
up from 9/22= 4,001 recently that is 22 stations in 13 days for about 160 more.
There were 224 stations in July/Aug/Sept/part Oct.

9/30= 4,017 stations. June 30 = 3799 up from 9/22= 4,001 recently that is 16 stations in 8 days for about 180 more.
There were 218 stations in July/Aug/Sept. What will the total be in 3 more months? Will there be another 218?
With poor weather, limited budgets the answer could be right on the bubble. But I'll give the benefit of the doubt.

9/26= 4,010 stations. June 30 = 3799 up from 9/22= 4,001 recently that is 9 stations in 5 days. Not a robust sample.
This is like forecasting the weather using linear extrapolation. It works for a short while then, bam it doesn't. 
I see there are 6 stations temporarily unavailable and 7 planned. (There are also 66 private stations.) Budgets are my main concern, governments everywhere are struggling due to less income. This is clearly a luxury expense for governments. Private money making ventures not so much. I'll give a slight bias to 4200+ as the number continues to grow, albeit slowly.

Using a start point of June 30th with 3,799 stations, and 61 business days from then through Sept 27th, gives an average of 3.45 stations per business day.... With 62 business days to go until the end of this challenge, that produces 214 stations. We're currently at 4,010.

******* I just posted this, but then saw the data that @bobrown provided, June 30 - 3799.... which changes things quite a bit from what I outline below*********** We're still averaging just over 3 stations a day (using daily data going back to July 28th). I've used business days to calculate this average rather then every single day (so excluding weekends and holidays). We're currently at 4,010 stations complete with 62 days to go.....which gets us to 4,196..... just shy of the 3rd bucket. Things will have to pick up steam to get us to the 3rd bucket, and staying at 3 per work day won't cut it.  I'll be monitoring this daily and if there's no uptick week on week then I'll swing fully into the 2nd bucket.

9/22= 4,001 stations. June 30 = 3799 that is 202 stations in July/Aug/ 2/3 Sept. We have 3-1/3 months left. At the same rate per month that would add 241 stations by year end for 4242 stations. Assumes stations are added as easily in the winter as in the summer and that budgets are similar. Neither asssumption would appear to hold.
I will climb up on the fence and see if October budgets produce the same number of installs as Q3.

9/18= 4,001 stations. June 30 = 3799 that is 202 stations in July/Aug/ 2/3 Sept. We have 3-1/3 months left. At the same rate per month that would add 252 stations by year end for 4253 stations. The crowd forecasts 4200+ by year end. Will the installation rate hold during Q4?

9/18= 3,998 stations. June 30 = 3799 that is 199 stations in July/Aug/ half Sept. We have 3-1/2 months left. At the same rate per month that would add 279 stations by year end for 4277 stations. The crowd forecasts 4200+ by year end. Using average installs per month is a good approximation. But I think budget and weather need to be factored in. The Federal government uses a year that ends Oct 1. Other municipalities may do the same, therefore funding from public sources may be unreliable. Weather the last time I looked influences some construction projects. And we have a lot of non-working holidays between now and then. I say its a toss up.
3,994 currently built. Pace has been slowing. Updating forecast.

Between July 28 and September 18 we've averaged 3.16 stations per work day (excluding weekends and holidays). There are 68 work days between September 18 and December 31. Assuming we stay close to ~3 stations per work day, we'll hit 4,209 stations by December 31.  I'll keep updating the daily tally from the alternative fuels website in the comments of my previous forecast. There you can find a near daily tracker since July 28.

In the past 14 days we've seen a net gain of 2. However, in those 14 days the Alternative Fuels website has jumped from 3,982 (Sep 2) down to 3,966 (Sep 10) and is now back up to 3,984 (Sep 16). I think at this point the question sponsor needs to reconsider this website as the source that the final answer will be based on. It does not seem reliable.
I've done poorly on previous questions of this nature: EVs and AVs.  Over-optimistic.  So, I have to keep my optimism in check.
3,974 as of today. As @mikemobbs mentioned, numbers are going up and down on a daily basis [1].  [1] https://www.gjopen.com/comments/1129231

The number of fast charging stations dropped to 3974 on 9/13 (from 3982 on 8/30), maybe decommissioning old stations?  The daily rate needed to reach 4200 is about 2, so still likely to be achieved, but reducing the probability of exceeding 4200 to reflect changing numbers.
At 3973 now. This makes 173 over 10 weeks. We have 15.5 weeks to go giving us an extrapolation of 268 additional stations for the year.
3,975 as of today. I was a bit overambitious with my forecast yesterday.
The average deployment rate for August was about 2.9 stations per day and the rate needed to exceed 4200 by December 31, 2020 is only 1.75.  This is seeming more and more likely.
Averaged 4.5 per work day over the last month (with the huge surge recorded in the last 24 hours)..... only need to average 2.5 per work day between now and Dec 31.
3976 as of 8/28. It’s been increasing more than 3 per day on average, putting it right above 4200 by the end of this year. But installations might slow down as winter comes (?)

Going all in on the 3,900 to 4,200 bracket (for now). With 83 work days left (as of Aug 27), even if we see a daily average of 3 stations, that only gets us to 4,190. In the past thirty days we've averaged about 2.9 stations per work day. Unless I see a significant uptick over the next 30 days, I think we'll stay below 4,200.
3,931 as of today. 12 more stations in the last 16 days.

I'm downgrading because over the last two weeks there has been relatively little change in the number of stations built. Aug 10 showed 3,919.... it shot up to 3,932 at one point... but now its back down to 3,923. Its shooting up and down, which seems odd.

Down two stations since last week. So 130 stations per 7 weeks. This still points to the second to last bracket but makes it less likely relative to the lower bracket. Also makes the last bracket quite a bit less likely.

Pace has increased slightly, updating forecast for latest data. Fair value of estimate is just on the above 4200.  https://afdc.energy.gov/fuels/electricity_locations.html#/analyze?country=US&fuel=ELEC&ev_levels=dc_fast

Currently there are 3926 stations, and 231 have opened since March for which timestamp data exists (less than half). This suggests to me that 4200 is quite easy to be reached by year end, and 4500 is remotely possible.

Current number (16th of august): 3932. That is 132 new in 6 weeks. 19.5 weeks to go. Simple extrapolation: 4361
However, it does seem somewhat plausible that fewer stations would be installed during the winter. 
Forecast without considering the crowd: 0|22|65|13 
crowd: 0|57|43|0
corrected forecast: 0|35|45|10
3,919 as of today. 19 more stations in the last 7 days.

Number of stations is up to 3919 on 8/9/2020, which means the per-day rate is (slightly) down to 1.94.  Last week's per-day rate was 2.7, so I am increasing the estimated likelihood of exceeding 4200 by Dec. 31, 2020.

Over the past 35 days we've averaged 3.2 stations per day (inclusive of weekends, so the build rate is higher if you just account for a 5 day work week). We're still on track to just punch past 4,200.
3,900 as of today. Increase by 34 in the last eight days.

Using a "per-day" rate (as opposed to a per-work-day rate) and the 8/2/2020 total from AFDC of 3900 fast ev stations, stations will need to come on line at 1.98 stations per day to reach 4200 by the closing date (152 days from now).  The historical rates are at or above that rate for the last few years and there isn't much evidence that this is going to change this year, despite covid.  I'm increasing the likelihood that more that 4200 stations are online by Dec 31, 2020.

Seeing a slight uptick in stations built per day from 2.9 to 3.6 averaged out over 28 days since July 2. I've been posting daily station numbers in the comments of one of my earlier forecasts for an easy to access reference. There are 100 business days from today (Aug 1) until Dec 31. There are 152 calendar days, and it does appear that stations are built over some weekends and holidays (although this could also be a lag in reporting on the Alternative Fuels website). If we only hit our 28 day average of 3 per day, we'll just pass the 4,200 mark.  I think this is much more likely now.
My old, weird low-end no-weekend, holidays off mental model puts us at 4296 EoY. C19 will potentially drag the numbers down further. https://www.gjopen.com/comments/1079788

I began with the historical growth rates for fast DC-EV charging stations, which are around 20-21% annual increase for the last 4-5 years.  I also looked at the Tesla supercharger network growth rates, which are higher at about 24-26% annual increases.  Covid likely reduced construction of fast charging stations due to supply chain disruption and workplace social distancing.  Tesla also reported rebounds in the usage of the supercharger network following the first collapse in usage at covid outbreak, which might suggest that construction of new stations remains a priority.  However, Tesla doesn't build all the public fast ev charging stations, so the growth rate is likely to be closer to the overall historical 20% rate and that rate (combined with the current AFDC data) translates to 4200 stations at year end.  The net effect of covid should be to push that downward.  More downward pressure could result from the unexpected fall in EV sales in 2019, although that effect could be counterbalanced (in part) because charging infrastructure is a long range proposition.  Overall, the 20% growth rate (4200 stations by year end) seems like the high end of the likely range.

155 days until Dec 31 (as of Jul 29) 155 x (5/7) = 110.7 work days (although it appears that some stations are added over the weekend as well) 110.7 x 3 (the average number of stations built per day since July 2) = 332 332 + 3,877 (number of stations as of July 29 @ 1315 CST) = 4209

Small sample size, but still averaging 3 new stations a day. If this remains consistent - and I can't say for certain how much time is adequate (1 month of construction data? 2?) - then I'm going to start to weight 4,200 and above more heavily.
3,866 as of today. Increase by 1 more station in the last eight days.

Sources: Today there are 3,865 stations, that's an increase of 66 since July 2 (ref:https://www.gjopen.com/comments/1070739). At this rate of three a day, that's about 480 stations - getting us to 4,345 stations  by January. This assumes no increase or decrease in production because of COVID, weather, construction over some weekends, etc....  Some other thoughts: It looks like Electrify America alone will build enough stations to move past 3,900 (https://www.electrifyamerica.com/assets/pdf/Cycle%202%20National%20ZEV%20Investment%20Plan%20-%20Public%20Version%20vF.50bb1fe0.pdf) In 2019, Electrify America opened stations at a rate of 1.2 per business day: https://www.underhoodservice.com/electrify-america-completes-ev-fast-charging-route/ They currently list 104 as "coming soon" - https://www.electrifyamerica.com/locate-charger/ Tesla lists 315 as "coming soon" with a target of 2020: https://www.tesla.com/findus/list/superchargers/United+States I think its most likely that we hit 3,900 but remain below 4,200. Tesla and Electrify America would have to meet 100% of their projections to get above 4,200 (not accounting for other companies like EVgo or ChargePoint, who are also building chargers).

Tesla and Electrify America would have to meet 100% of their projections to get above 4,200 (not accounting for other companies like EVgo or ChargePoint, who are also building chargers),
3,865 as of today. Increase by 11 stations in the last two days.
3,854 as of today. Increase by 13 stations in the last 3 days.
EV charging will begin to accelerate in 2020-2021

3853 as of today and 5.5 months to go.
I've seen figures of at least 20% YoY growth. So the adjusted remaining under normal circumstances would add 353 more. Give or take a generous buffer of 25%... 265-441 So for now, 4118-4295 Here's where it gets weird...
It looks like they are building like crazy right now. I imagine this work is seasonal but even despite the economy and pandemic, growth has been impressive over the last 9 days. Looking at recent post C19 performance, we are talking an uptick of +53 in 9 days.
I presume this is as low as it'll go except a pause in the last 2-3 weeks of December. That is 5.89 /day. Days until 31 DEC 2020: 170
Minus holidays and holiday slow downs: 145-149 So current EoY output puts us at +854-1000 (!!)
If we exclude weekends: 610-715
If we exclude weekends AND the last month and a half of the year: 443-510 (starting to get plausible.) Point being, I don't know much about the industry, but it does seem to be running at a steady clip right now despite C19 etc. I imagine this is the "busy season" and it reasonably would cover the summer and fall months.
I'm confused in general. Interesting to learn about though. Excited to see what research everyone else digs up. We hope you've enjoyed this episode of Adventures in Wild Conjecture and Pseudo-Science.

3,841 stations available as of today [1]. Increase by 42 stations within the last 10 days [2]. Need for close observation in the coming days to avoid underestimating or overestimating the overall development. [1] https://afdc.energy.gov/fuels/electricity_locations.html#/analyze?country=US&fuel=ELEC&ev_levels=dc_fast
[2] https://www.gjopen.com/comments/1070739

The economic shutdown / slowdown makes me shy off the thought that growth will be steady.  But we haven't yet hit a ceiling on the demand, so I'm betting growth continues more or less on this current pace with a mild dip because of CV.

Hmmm...seems that 30 stations have been added since I last answered this question a week ago. There are about 24 weeks remaining in the year. Employ people by completing funded projects - a great idea. At 30/week with 20 working weeks left in the year that is 500-600 more stations. 3800+500 = 4300 stations by year end. However, budgets may be constrained as the economy slows, so weight the lower estimate more.

Hattip @Flo_Dorner for pointing out my incorrect assumptions.
June 30 = 3799 Fast Charging Stations in the US. Built over the last 9-1/2 years. That's about 400 stations / year. Clearly there is more of a need now than in 2011. Assume built rate for remainder of 2020 is 400/yr. Q1-Q2 2020 saw at least 242 Fast Chargers installed - 2019 = 240/year, 2018=250, 2017=95.
3800+200 = 4K, then  detune forecast for the Covid-19 budget impact effect. The last step is the hard part. This is where we go into a trance and grab a bunch of numbers from a hat.

Current number: 3800 (5th of july)
Previous numbers: 2318 (29th of june 2018) https://www.gjopen.com/questions/591-on-29-june-2018-how-many-public-dc-fast-charge-electric-vehicle-charging-stations-will-be-available-in-the-united-states
Sadly, the source does not seem to make historical data available and their dataset contains opening dates only sparsely. 
This gives us a very rough estimate of around 1500 stations in the last two years. Extrapolation would then yield 4175, but seasonal effects and the corona crisis make this estimate quite shaky. 
Forecast without looking at crowd: 5|55|25|15 Crowd: 0|73|26|1
Corrected forecast: 2|65|25|8

June 30 there are 3799 Fast Charging Stations in the US. Built over the last 9-1/2 years. That's about 400 stations per year. Clearly there is more of a need now than in 2011. Assume built rate for remainder of 2020 is 2.K/yr. FIrst half of 2020 saw at least 1376 Fast Charger installed while 2019 saw about 2K/year.
3799+1000 = 4800 detune forecast for the Covid-19 budget impact effect.
